metadata.description: Duct sizing, static pressure, fittings, airflow, Manual D calculations

questions.question: What is the industry standard method for sizing residential duct systems?

choices.b: ACCA Manual D

explanation.short: ACCA Manual D is the industry standard for residential duct design and sizing.
explanation.detailed: Manual D (Residential Duct Systems) provides the methodology for sizing supply and return ducts based on equipment airflow requirements from Manual S and room-by-room loads from Manual J. It accounts for available static pressure, fitting losses, and duct materials. Most building codes reference Manual D for residential duct design.

questions.question: What unit is commonly used to measure static pressure in duct systems?

choices.b: Inches of water column (in. w.c.)

explanation.short: Duct static pressure is measured in inches of water column (in. w.c. or iwc).
explanation.detailed: Static pressure in HVAC duct systems is relatively low compared to plumbing or refrigerant systems. Inches of water column is the standard unit - 1 in. w.c. equals about 0.036 PSI. Typical residential systems operate at 0.5 in. w.c. total external static pressure. Manometers and digital pressure gauges read in in. w.c.

questions.question: What does TESP stand for in duct design?

choices.b: Total External Static Pressure

explanation.short: TESP is Total External Static Pressure - the pressure the blower must overcome external to the equipment.
explanation.detailed: Total External Static Pressure is the sum of all pressure drops in the duct system external to the air handler. It includes supply ducts, return ducts, registers, grilles, filters, and any accessories. Equipment is rated for maximum TESP - typically 0.5 in. w.c. for residential. Exceeding rated TESP reduces airflow and efficiency.

questions.question: In duct sizing, what does friction rate represent?

choices.b: Pressure drop per 100 feet of duct

explanation.short: Friction rate is the pressure drop in inches w.c. per 100 feet of straight duct.
explanation.detailed: Friction rate allows consistent duct sizing across different run lengths. It's expressed as in. w.c. per 100 ft of duct. Manual D calculates available friction rate by dividing available static pressure by total effective length (including fitting equivalents). Typical residential friction rates range from 0.05 to 0.10 in. w.c./100 ft.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference friction rate calculation in Manual D

questions.question: What is the typical airflow rate per ton of cooling for residential systems?

choices.b: 400 CFM per ton

explanation.short: Standard airflow is 400 CFM per ton of cooling capacity for residential systems.
explanation.detailed: The 400 CFM/ton rule is a baseline for standard humidity conditions. Actual requirements may vary: humid climates may use 350 CFM/ton for better dehumidification; dry climates may use 450 CFM/ton. Manual S provides specific airflow requirements based on equipment selection and sensible heat ratio. Always verify with manufacturer data.

questions.question: What is the maximum recommended velocity for residential trunk ducts to minimize noise?

choices.b: 700 FPM

explanation.short: Maximum trunk duct velocity of 900 FPM is recommended to control noise in residential systems.
explanation.detailed: Air velocity creates noise - higher velocity means more noise. Manual D recommends: trunk ducts 700-900 FPM max, branch ducts 600 FPM max, and flex duct runouts even lower. Commercial systems tolerate higher velocities due to ambient noise. Exceeding velocity limits causes complaints even if ducts are properly sized for pressure drop.

questions.question: What does equivalent length represent for duct fittings?

choices.a: Actual physical length of the fitting
choices.b: Length of straight duct with same pressure drop as the fitting

explanation.short: Equivalent length converts fitting pressure drop to an equivalent length of straight duct for easier calculations.
explanation.detailed: Fittings (elbows, tees, transitions) cause pressure drops that vary by fitting type and velocity. Equivalent length expresses this as feet of straight duct with the same loss. A 90° elbow might have 15-25 ft equivalent length. Total effective length = straight duct + sum of all fitting equivalent lengths. Manual D provides equivalent length tables.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual D fitting equivalent length tables

questions.question: Compared to smooth metal duct, what is true about flexible duct friction loss?

choices.a: Flex duct has lower friction loss
choices.b: Flex duct has higher friction loss when fully stretched
choices.d: Flex duct has no friction loss

explanation.short: Flexible duct has significantly higher friction loss than smooth metal, even when fully stretched.
explanation.detailed: Flex duct's corrugated interior creates turbulence and higher friction. When fully extended (stretched tight), friction is about 1.5x that of smooth metal. When compressed or sagging, friction can be 3-5x higher. Manual D requires flex duct be pulled taut with no more than 4% compression. Many systems underperform due to poorly installed flex duct.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual D flex duct friction factors

questions.question: How should return air duct size compare to supply duct size?

choices.a: Return should be smaller than supply
choices.b: Return should equal supply exactly
choices.c: Return should be larger than supply to reduce velocity

explanation.short: Return ducts should be larger than supply to accommodate lower velocities and reduce noise near living spaces.
explanation.detailed: Return ducts are typically located in living spaces where noise is critical. Lower velocities (400-600 FPM) require larger duct sizes. Additionally, return grilles have less free area than supply registers, requiring more gross area. A common guideline: return duct cross-sectional area should be at least 1.0-1.2 times supply. Undersized returns cause high static, reduced airflow, and noise.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference return air sizing in Manual D

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable duct leakage rate for sealed duct systems per energy codes?

choices.b: 4 CFM per 100 sq ft at 25 Pa

explanation.short: Energy codes typically limit duct leakage to 4 CFM per 100 sq ft of conditioned floor area at 25 Pa test pressure.
explanation.detailed: Duct leakage wastes energy by losing conditioned air to unconditioned spaces. IECC and most state energy codes require duct testing. Maximum leakage is typically 4 CFM/100 sq ft (some jurisdictions require 3 CFM). Test at 25 Pa (0.1 in. w.c.). Leakage is measured with duct blaster equipment. Sealing with mastic or approved tape is required at all joints.

questions.question: What is the minimum insulation R-value required for ducts in unconditioned spaces per most energy codes?

explanation.short: R-8 is the typical minimum for supply ducts in unconditioned spaces; some climates require R-6 for return.
explanation.detailed: IECC requires minimum R-8 insulation for supply ducts and R-6 for return ducts in unconditioned spaces (attics, crawlspaces, garages). Climate zones may have different requirements. Ducts in conditioned spaces may not require insulation. Insulation prevents energy loss and condensation on cold supply ducts. Duct wrap, duct board, or lined duct all count toward R-value.

questions.question: According to the IMC, what spaces are prohibited from being used as return air plenums?

choices.b: Garages, bathrooms, kitchens, and spaces containing fuel-burning appliances

explanation.short: Garages, bathrooms, kitchens, and mechanical rooms with fuel-burning equipment cannot be used as return plenums.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 601.2 prohibits certain spaces from serving as return air sources due to contaminant concerns. Garages have exhaust fumes; kitchens have cooking byproducts; bathrooms have odors/humidity; mechanical rooms may have combustion products. Return air from these spaces would distribute contaminants throughout the building. Direct duct return from these spaces is also prohibited.

questions.question: When are fire dampers required in duct systems?

choices.b: Where ducts penetrate fire-resistance-rated assemblies

explanation.short: Fire dampers are required where ducts penetrate fire-resistance-rated walls, floors, and ceiling assemblies.
explanation.detailed: Fire dampers automatically close when exposed to heat (typically 165°F fusible link), preventing fire and smoke spread through duct penetrations. Required at fire barriers, fire partitions, smoke barriers, and shaft enclosures per IMC Chapter 6 and IBC. Some penetrations may use fire/smoke damper combinations. Access for inspection and testing must be provided. Residential applications rarely require them.

questions.question: What is the most common gauge of sheet metal used for residential rectangular duct trunks?

choices.b: 26 gauge

explanation.short: 26 gauge galvanized steel is standard for residential duct trunks up to 12 inches.
explanation.detailed: SMACNA standards specify minimum metal gauges based on duct size and pressure class. For residential (low pressure, 0.5-1 in. w.c.), 26 gauge is typical for ducts up to 12 inches. Larger ducts require heavier gauge (24 or 22) for rigidity. Branch ducts 8 inches and smaller may use 28 gauge. Remember: lower gauge number = thicker metal.

questions.question: What is the preferred method for sealing duct joints?

choices.b: Mastic sealant or UL-listed foil tape

explanation.short: Water-based mastic or UL 181-listed metal foil tape are approved methods for duct sealing.
explanation.detailed: Traditional cloth 'duct tape' fails quickly due to heat cycling and is NOT approved for duct sealing. Proper methods: (1) Water-based mastic applied with brush over joints and seams; (2) UL 181A-listed foil tape for rigid duct or UL 181B-listed tape for flex duct. Mastic is preferred for longevity. All transverse joints, longitudinal seams, and duct connections must be sealed.

questions.question: What is the maximum recommended aspect ratio for rectangular ducts?

explanation.short: Maximum 4:1 aspect ratio is recommended; higher ratios increase friction and material costs.
explanation.detailed: Aspect ratio is the ratio of duct width to height. Higher aspect ratios (flatter ducts) have more perimeter per unit area, increasing friction loss, material use, and noise. Manual D recommends staying at or below 4:1. A 24x6 duct (4:1) has more friction than a 16x9 duct (1.78:1) of equivalent area. Round duct has 1:1 aspect ratio and lowest friction.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference aspect ratio in Manual D

questions.question: Which duct shape has the lowest friction loss for a given cross-sectional area?

choices.b: Square

explanation.short: Round duct has the lowest friction loss because it has the minimum perimeter for a given area.
explanation.detailed: Friction occurs at duct walls. Round duct has the smallest perimeter-to-area ratio, minimizing friction. For equal capacity: round < oval < square < rectangular (with high aspect ratio). Round is also stronger, easier to seal, and uses less material. Its main disadvantage is height requirement. Spiral round duct with gasketed fittings is the highest-performing option.

questions.question: What does 'throw' refer to in supply register selection?

choices.b: Distance air travels before velocity drops to a specified terminal velocity

explanation.short: Throw is the horizontal distance supply air travels before velocity drops to terminal velocity (typically 50 FPM).
explanation.detailed: Supply registers must deliver air to the occupied zone without drafts. Throw is measured to a terminal velocity (usually 50 or 75 FPM). Proper throw reaches 75% of the distance to the opposite wall. Too short = poor mixing and hot/cold spots. Too long = drafty. Throw is affected by register type, outlet velocity, and ceiling height. Manual T covers register selection.

questions.question: What does 'spread' refer to in supply air register performance?

choices.b: Width of the air pattern perpendicular to throw direction

explanation.short: Spread is the width of the air pattern perpendicular to the primary airflow direction.
explanation.detailed: Spread describes how wide the air pattern fans out from a register. Different register types have different spread characteristics: linear slot diffusers have narrow spread; 4-way ceiling diffusers have 360° spread. Spread combined with throw determines coverage pattern. Proper spread ensures air reaches all parts of the room without dead spots.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual T register performance data

questions.question: What is the airflow (CFM) through a 12-inch round duct at 800 FPM velocity?

choices.b: 628 CFM

explanation.short: CFM = Area × Velocity. Area = π × (6/12)² = 0.785 sq ft. CFM = 0.785 × 800 = 628 CFM.
explanation.detailed: Calculate: (1) Convert diameter to feet: 12 in ÷ 12 = 1 ft; (2) Calculate area: π × r² = 3.14159 × 0.5² = 0.785 sq ft; (3) Multiply by velocity: 0.785 × 800 FPM = 628 CFM. This formula (Q = A × V) is fundamental to duct sizing. Memorize common duct areas or use a duct calculator.

questions.question: What is the purpose of balancing dampers in a duct system?

choices.b: Adjust airflow to each branch for proper distribution

explanation.short: Balancing dampers allow adjustment of airflow to individual branches to achieve design CFM at each outlet.
explanation.detailed: Even well-designed systems may not deliver exact design CFM to each room due to installation variations. Balancing dampers (manual or automatic) in branch takeoffs allow field adjustment. During commissioning, a balancer measures CFM at each register and adjusts dampers until design values are achieved. Dampers should be accessible for future adjustment.

questions.question: What is the purpose of turning vanes in duct elbows?

choices.b: Reduce pressure drop and improve airflow uniformity through the turn

explanation.short: Turning vanes guide airflow through elbows, reducing turbulence, pressure loss, and noise.
explanation.detailed: Sharp 90° elbows create turbulence and high pressure drop. Turning vanes (curved blades inside the elbow) redirect airflow smoothly around the turn. Benefits: reduced pressure drop (up to 50% less than square elbow without vanes), more uniform velocity profile exiting the elbow, reduced noise. Most effective in square/rectangular elbows; round elbows typically use long-radius turns instead.

questions.question: What centerline radius-to-diameter ratio is considered a 'long radius' elbow for round duct?

explanation.short: A long-radius elbow has centerline radius of 1.5 times the duct diameter or greater.
explanation.detailed: Elbow radius significantly affects pressure drop. Short radius (R/D < 1) has high losses; long radius (R/D ≥ 1.5) has much lower losses. For example, a 12-inch diameter duct with long-radius 90° elbow needs 18-inch centerline radius minimum. Manual D equivalent lengths: short radius 90° = 30 ft; long radius 90° = 10 ft. Always use long radius when space permits.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference elbow equivalent lengths in Manual D

questions.question: Which type of branch takeoff fitting has the lowest pressure loss?

choices.b: 45° conical takeoff

explanation.short: A 45° conical (angled) takeoff has lower pressure loss than a straight 90° tap.
explanation.detailed: Branch takeoffs remove air from trunk ducts. A straight 90° tap forces air to make an abrupt turn, creating turbulence. A conical or 45° takeoff gradually redirects air, reducing losses. Even better: use a radius takeoff or register boot with turning vanes. Manual D provides equivalent lengths: 90° tap = 35 ft; 45° conical = 10 ft typical.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual D fitting equivalent lengths

questions.question: What is the maximum recommended angle for a duct transition (reducer/enlarger)?

choices.b: 15° per side

explanation.short: Maximum 15° per side (30° included angle) prevents flow separation and high pressure loss.
explanation.detailed: Abrupt size changes cause turbulence. Gradual transitions allow airflow to follow the duct walls. For reducers (supply) and enlargers (return/exhaust): keep each wall angle at or below 15° from centerline. Steeper angles cause separation, recirculation zones, and noise. If space is limited, use a lower-loss fitting like an offset box or add turning vanes.

questions.question: What is the maximum support spacing for horizontal round duct 12 inches in diameter?

choices.b: 8 feet

explanation.short: SMACNA specifies maximum 10-foot support spacing for round duct 12 inches and larger.
explanation.detailed: Duct supports prevent sagging, joint separation, and damage. SMACNA guidelines: round duct up to 8 inches = 8 ft max spacing; 10 inches and larger = 10 ft max. Rectangular duct varies by size and gauge. Supports must not compress insulation or damage vapor barriers. Flexible duct requires more frequent support (4-5 ft max) to prevent sagging.

questions.question: What is the maximum support spacing for flexible duct?

choices.b: 5 feet

explanation.short: Flexible duct must be supported at maximum 5-foot intervals per IMC.
explanation.detailed: Flex duct sags between supports, creating low spots that restrict airflow and collect condensation. IMC 603.6 requires support at intervals not exceeding 5 feet for horizontal runs. Supports should be at least 1.5 inches wide to avoid compressing the duct. Flex must be stretched taut with no more than 4% compression for proper airflow.

questions.question: A furnace is rated for 0.5 in. w.c. TESP. The filter has 0.10 in. w.c. drop and coil has 0.15 in. w.c. drop. What static pressure is available for ductwork?

explanation.short: Available for duct = TESP - Filter - Coil = 0.50 - 0.10 - 0.15 = 0.25 in. w.c.
explanation.detailed: Equipment is rated for Total External Static Pressure (TESP). All external accessories consume part of this budget: filter, coil, humidifier, dampers, etc. What remains is available for supply and return duct system. Calculate: 0.50 (rated) - 0.10 (filter) - 0.15 (coil) = 0.25 in. w.c. for ducts. This must be split between supply (typically 60%) and return (40%).
explanation.how_to_find: Subtract accessory losses from rated TESP

questions.question: In duct design, what is the critical path?

choices.b: The duct run with highest total effective length (highest pressure drop)

explanation.short: The critical path is the duct run with the highest total effective length, determining the system friction rate.
explanation.detailed: Manual D sizes ducts based on the critical (longest) path - the run from equipment to the furthest outlet with highest total equivalent length. This path requires the most pressure to deliver design CFM. Available static pressure divided by critical path length determines friction rate. All other paths are shorter and will receive adequate (or excess) airflow if the critical path is properly sized.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference critical path in Manual D methodology

questions.question: What is duct board made from?

choices.b: Rigid fiberglass with foil facing

explanation.short: Duct board is rigid fiberglass insulation with reinforced aluminum foil facing, formed into ducts.
explanation.detailed: Duct board is fabricated on-site from rigid fiberglass panels (typically R-4.2 to R-8). The exterior has reinforced aluminum foil facing that serves as vapor barrier and structural surface. Interior may be faced with film for cleanability or left fibrous. Advantages: built-in insulation, quiet, lightweight. Disadvantages: harder to seal, can harbor mold if wet, limited to low-pressure applications.

questions.question: What is the difference between a fire damper and a smoke damper?

choices.b: Fire dampers close on heat; smoke dampers close on smoke detection signal
choices.c: Smoke dampers are only for exhaust systems
choices.d: Fire dampers are motorized; smoke dampers are gravity

explanation.short: Fire dampers close automatically on heat (fusible link); smoke dampers close on signal from smoke detector or fire alarm.
explanation.detailed: Fire dampers: close when fusible link (typically 165°F) melts, stopping fire spread through duct penetration. Self-contained, no wiring needed. Smoke dampers: motor-operated, close when signaled by smoke detector or building fire alarm to prevent smoke migration before fire reaches them. Many applications require combination fire/smoke dampers. IMC Chapter 6 specifies where each is required.

questions.question: What is the difference between a grille and a register?

choices.b: A register has a damper; a grille does not
choices.c: Grilles are for supply; registers are for return
choices.d: Grilles are round; registers are rectangular

explanation.short: A register has a built-in damper for airflow control; a grille is simply a louvered cover with no damper.
explanation.detailed: Terminology: Grille = fixed louvers or perforated face, no flow control. Register = grille plus operable damper (opposed blade or single blade) for adjusting airflow. Diffuser = typically ceiling-mounted with radial air pattern. Supply outlets are usually registers for balancing ability. Return/exhaust may use grilles since no balancing is needed at the individual opening.

questions.question: What does 'free area' refer to for a register or grille?

choices.b: Open area through which air can actually flow

explanation.short: Free area is the actual open area available for airflow, excluding louvers, frame, and damper.
explanation.detailed: A 12x12 register has 144 sq in gross area, but louvers and frame block much of it. Free area is typically 60-80% of gross area depending on design. Airflow calculations must use free area, not overall size. Manufacturers publish free area data. Undersized free area causes high velocity, noise, and pressure drop. Return grilles typically need more free area than supply due to lower allowed velocity.

questions.question: What does NC rating measure for diffusers and grilles?

choices.b: Noise Criteria - the sound level generated at a given CFM

explanation.short: NC (Noise Criteria) rating indicates the sound level a diffuser produces at specified airflow.
explanation.detailed: NC is a single-number rating of octave-band sound levels. Lower NC = quieter. Typical design targets: bedrooms NC-25 to NC-35; offices NC-35 to NC-40; commercial/retail NC-40 to NC-45. Manufacturers publish NC ratings vs. CFM. Exceeding rated CFM dramatically increases noise. Diffuser selection must consider both airflow capacity and acceptable noise level for the space.

questions.question: What is the typical recommended filter face velocity for standard pleated filters?

explanation.short: Standard pleated filters are typically sized for 300-400 FPM face velocity.
explanation.detailed: Filter face velocity affects pressure drop and efficiency. Higher velocity = higher pressure drop and potential filter bypass. Standard 1-2 inch pleated filters: 300-400 FPM. High-efficiency filters (MERV 13+): 250-300 FPM. Media air cleaners: 100-150 FPM. To calculate filter size needed: Area (sq ft) = CFM ÷ face velocity. A 1200 CFM system at 400 FPM needs 3 sq ft = 432 sq in filter area.

questions.question: What does MERV stand for in filter ratings?

choices.b: Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value

explanation.short: MERV is Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value - a standardized filter efficiency rating from 1-16.
explanation.detailed: MERV rates filter effectiveness at capturing particles of specific sizes per ASHRAE Standard 52.2. Scale is 1 (lowest) to 16 (highest for HVAC filters). MERV 8 = standard residential; MERV 11-13 = enhanced residential/commercial; MERV 14-16 = hospital/clean room. Higher MERV = more pressure drop; system must be designed for it. HEPA filters rate above MERV 16 on different scales.

questions.question: In a heating-dominated climate, where should return air grilles ideally be located?

choices.b: Low on interior walls

explanation.short: Low returns work best for heating; they draw cool air from the floor level where it settles.
explanation.detailed: Hot air rises and stratifies at ceiling level; cold air settles to floor. Low returns pull the coldest air (floor level) to be reheated, improving comfort and efficiency. In cooling-dominated climates, high returns pull the warmest stratified air for cooling. Ideal systems have both high and low returns with seasonal changeover. Most homes compromise with central returns.

questions.question: Why are supply registers often located on exterior walls or under windows?

choices.b: To counteract heat loss/gain at the building envelope

explanation.short: Perimeter supply offsets heat loss through walls/windows and prevents cold drafts from reaching occupants.
explanation.detailed: Windows and exterior walls are primary sources of heat loss (winter) and gain (summer). Perimeter supply outlets discharge conditioned air to counteract these loads before they affect room temperature. Floor registers under windows create an air curtain that prevents cold glass radiation from reaching occupants. High sidewall supplies on exterior walls achieve similar results. Interior outlets may cause comfort complaints.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference supply outlet placement in Manual T

questions.question: What component is essential for a zoned duct system to control airflow to different areas?

choices.b: Zone dampers

explanation.short: Zone dampers in branch ducts open/close to direct airflow to zones calling for conditioning.
explanation.detailed: Zoning divides a home into independently controlled areas. Zone dampers (motorized or pneumatic) install in ducts serving each zone. When a zone thermostat calls, its damper opens. A zone panel coordinates damper positions and equipment operation. Bypass dampers or variable-speed blowers handle excess static when zones close. Proper design prevents pressure and airflow problems.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a bypass damper in a zoned duct system?

choices.b: Relieve excess static pressure when zones close

explanation.short: Bypass dampers redirect excess airflow back to return when zone dampers close, preventing high static pressure.
explanation.detailed: When zones close, blower output has nowhere to go, causing high static pressure that reduces airflow, increases noise, and stresses equipment. A bypass damper connects supply to return plenum. When zone dampers close, bypass opens proportionally to maintain acceptable static. Some systems use variable-speed blowers instead, which reduce airflow as zones close, eliminating the need for bypass.

questions.question: What does a pitot tube measure when used in duct testing?

choices.b: Total and static pressure (to calculate velocity pressure)

explanation.short: A pitot tube measures total pressure and static pressure; the difference is velocity pressure.
explanation.detailed: A pitot-static tube has two ports: impact tip facing airflow (measures total pressure = static + velocity) and side holes (measure static pressure only). Connected to a manometer, the difference gives velocity pressure. Velocity = 4005 × √(VP). Traversing the duct with multiple readings and averaging calculates average velocity; multiply by area for CFM. Essential for air balancing.

questions.question: If velocity pressure is 0.04 in. w.c., what is the air velocity?

choices.b: 600 FPM

explanation.detailed: The velocity formula for standard air (70°F, 29.92 in. Hg) is V = 4005 × √VP, where VP is velocity pressure in inches w.c. Calculate: √0.04 = 0.2; 4005 × 0.2 = 801 FPM. This formula derives from Bernoulli's equation. For non-standard conditions (altitude, temperature), a density correction factor applies. Most residential/light commercial work uses standard conditions.

questions.question: What instrument directly measures air velocity at a register or grille?

choices.b: Velometer or rotating vane anemometer

explanation.short: A velometer or rotating vane anemometer directly reads air velocity in FPM at outlets.
explanation.detailed: For measuring airflow at registers, anemometers are faster than pitot tube traverses. Rotating vane anemometers spin proportionally to velocity. Hot wire anemometers sense cooling of a heated element. Hood (capture) type anemometers measure total CFM from a register. Each has accuracy limitations. Traverse the entire register face and average for best results.

questions.question: What is the advantage of using a flow capture hood for measuring register airflow?

choices.b: Directly reads total CFM without calculations

explanation.short: A capture hood directly displays CFM by capturing and measuring all air from the register.
explanation.detailed: Flow capture hoods cover the entire register face, capturing all airflow. A built-in velocity sensor and known hood area (or direct measurement grid) display CFM directly. No traversing or calculations needed. Faster than other methods for balancing. Accuracy depends on proper seal to ceiling/wall and correct hood size. Back pressure from the hood can slightly reduce actual flow; corrections may apply.

questions.question: What equipment is used to perform a duct leakage test?

choices.b: Duct blaster (calibrated fan with pressure gauges)

explanation.short: A duct blaster is a calibrated fan that pressurizes ducts while measuring airflow needed to maintain test pressure.
explanation.detailed: Duct leakage testing per energy codes uses a duct blaster (or duct tester). The device seals to the duct system and pressurizes it to 25 Pa (0.1 in. w.c.). The calibrated fan measures how much airflow is required to maintain that pressure - this equals the leakage rate. Leakage is compared to code maximums (typically 4 CFM/100 sq ft). All registers are temporarily sealed during test.

questions.question: What is an extended plenum duct system?

choices.a: A system with oversized plenums only
choices.b: A trunk that runs the length of the building at constant size with branches tapping off
choices.c: A system with no trunk ducts

explanation.short: Extended plenum systems have a constant-size main trunk with branch ducts tapping off along its length.
explanation.detailed: Extended plenum (also called constant-velocity or trunk-and-branch) systems run a single-size trunk from the equipment, with branches taking off at intervals. Simple to install but less efficient than reducing trunk systems because velocity and pressure distribution aren't optimized. Best used with short trunk runs. Reducing trunk systems reduce trunk size after each takeoff to maintain velocity.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference extended plenum design in Manual D

questions.question: What is the advantage of a reducing trunk duct system?

choices.b: Maintains proper velocity as airflow decreases along the trunk

explanation.short: Reducing trunk maintains proper velocity by decreasing trunk size as airflow decreases after each branch takeoff.
explanation.detailed: As air is removed by branch takeoffs, the remaining trunk flow decreases. If trunk size stays constant, velocity drops, causing poor air distribution to far outlets. A reducing trunk decreases in size after each takeoff to maintain design velocity. Better pressure distribution, quieter operation, and more even outlet airflow. Requires more fittings and careful design but performs better.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference reducing trunk design in Manual D

questions.question: What characterizes a radial duct system?

choices.a: Individual runs from equipment to each outlet with no trunk
choices.b: Multiple trunk ducts

explanation.short: Radial (spider or octopus) systems have individual ducts from a central plenum directly to each outlet.
explanation.detailed: Radial systems branch directly from the supply plenum to individual outlets without trunk ducts. Common in slab-on-grade homes with ducts in the slab or manufactured housing. Advantages: shorter total duct runs, simpler design, fewer fittings. Disadvantages: many connections at plenum, can be harder to balance, more total linear feet if outlets are distant. Often uses flex duct.

questions.question: What is a characteristic of high-velocity small duct systems?

choices.b: Small-diameter ducts (2-3 inch) with high velocity requiring special outlets

explanation.short: High-velocity systems use small (2-3 inch) round ducts at high velocity with special sound-attenuating outlets.
explanation.detailed: High-velocity systems (Unico, SpacePak) operate at 1500-2500 FPM using small flexible tubes. Benefits: easy retrofit, fit through small spaces, high throw from outlets. Challenges: special equipment required, higher fan energy, special outlets needed for noise attenuation (without them, noise would be excessive). Static pressure requirements are much higher (1-2 in. w.c.).

questions.question: A 10x8 rectangular duct has an equivalent round diameter of approximately:

choices.b: 9 inches

explanation.short: Equivalent diameter formula gives approximately 10 inches for a 10x8 rectangular duct.
explanation.detailed: Equivalent round diameter is the size of round duct with the same friction loss per unit length. Formula: De = 1.3 × (a×b)^0.625 / (a+b)^0.25, where a and b are rectangular dimensions. For 10x8: (80)^0.625 = 17.4; (18)^0.25 = 2.06; De = 1.3 × 17.4/2.06 = 11. Friction chart shows 10x8 rect ≈ 10-inch round. Equal area would give √(80/0.785) = 10.1 inches.
explanation.how_to_find: Use equivalent diameter tables or formula

questions.question: What pressure class is typical for residential duct systems?

choices.b: 3-inch w.c.

explanation.short: Residential systems typically operate at 1/2 to 1-inch w.c. (low pressure class).
explanation.detailed: SMACNA classifies ducts by operating pressure: low pressure (up to 2 in. w.c.), medium (2-6 in.), and high (6-10 in.). Residential is almost always low pressure, typically 0.5-1 in. w.c. TESP. Higher pressure classes require heavier gauge metal, more reinforcement, and better sealing. Commercial VAV systems may operate at 3-6 in. w.c.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of internal duct liner?

choices.b: Sound attenuation and thermal insulation

explanation.short: Internal duct liner provides acoustic absorption to reduce noise and thermal insulation.
explanation.detailed: Duct liner (fiberglass or foam with facing) adheres to inner duct surfaces. Primary benefits: absorbs fan and air noise, provides R-value for thermal control. Common in commercial systems and near air handlers. Disadvantages: reduces effective duct area, can harbor mold/bacteria if wet, fibers may release into airstream. Faced liner and proper maintenance are essential.

questions.question: What is a duct silencer used for?

choices.b: Reduce noise transmitted through ductwork

explanation.short: Duct silencers reduce fan and air noise by passing air through sound-absorbing baffles.
explanation.detailed: Silencers (also called sound attenuators or sound traps) install in ductwork to reduce noise transmission. They contain acoustic baffles or absorptive media that dissipate sound energy. Used near air handlers, rooftop units, or before noise-sensitive spaces. They add pressure drop (typically 0.1-0.3 in. w.c.) that must be accounted for in design. Size based on CFM and required noise reduction.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a flexible duct connector at an air handler?

choices.b: Isolate equipment vibration from the duct system

explanation.short: Flexible connectors isolate vibration from air handling equipment, preventing transmission through ductwork.
explanation.detailed: Air handlers, furnaces, and fans create vibration. Rigid duct connections transmit this vibration throughout the duct system, causing noise. Flexible connectors (canvas, neoprene, or other flexible material) at the equipment break the vibration path. IMC requires flexible connectors to be UL listed and to maintain duct pressure class. Keep them short (4-6 inches) to maintain aerodynamic performance.

questions.question: What is the advantage of double-wall duct construction?

choices.b: Smooth interior for low friction with external insulation for thermal and acoustic control

explanation.short: Double-wall duct has smooth inner liner and perforated outer shell with insulation between for acoustics and thermal performance.
explanation.detailed: Double-wall (or dual-wall) duct consists of: solid inner liner (low friction), insulation layer, and perforated outer shell (sound absorption). Benefits: smooth interior maintains low friction; insulation layer handles thermal; perforated outer with backing absorbs sound. Used in commercial buildings, hospitals, and critical spaces. More expensive but highest performance. Can also use solid outer shell with lined interior.

questions.question: What material is required for commercial kitchen exhaust duct construction?

choices.b: Minimum 16-gauge steel or 18-gauge stainless, welded and liquid tight

explanation.short: Commercial kitchen exhaust requires minimum 16-gauge steel or 18-gauge stainless with welded liquid-tight joints.
explanation.detailed: IMC Chapter 5 (and IMC 507) requires grease ducts to be: minimum 16-gauge carbon steel or 18-gauge stainless; continuously welded liquid tight (no screws, rivets, or snap lock); sloped to drain; with cleanout access. This construction contains grease-laden vapors and withstands periodic high-temperature cleaning. Listed factory-built grease duct systems are alternatives.

questions.question: What duct material is typically required for dryer exhaust?

choices.b: Rigid or semi-rigid metal

explanation.short: Dryer exhaust ducts must be rigid or semi-rigid metal to handle heat and resist lint accumulation.
explanation.detailed: IMC and IRC require dryer exhaust to be smooth-interior metal - galvanized steel, aluminum, or other approved metal. Flexible vinyl or plastic is prohibited (fire hazard). Corrugated metal flex may be used only for the final connection at the dryer (and limited to 8 ft equivalent length). Smooth metal resists lint buildup and reduces fire risk. Maximum length is 35 ft (with deductions for fittings).

questions.question: What is the maximum developed length for a residential dryer exhaust duct?

choices.b: 25 feet

explanation.short: Maximum dryer exhaust duct length is 35 feet, with deductions for each fitting.
explanation.detailed: IMC 504.6.4 limits dryer exhaust to 35 feet maximum developed length. Deduct for fittings: 45° elbow = 2.5 ft; 90° elbow = 5 ft. Example: 2 elbows (10 ft deduction) limits straight run to 25 ft. Longer runs require manufacturer's instructions for approved extended lengths with booster fans. Keep runs short and straight to reduce lint accumulation and fire hazard.

questions.question: What is the minimum exhaust rate for a residential bathroom without a window?

choices.b: 50 CFM continuous or 100 CFM intermittent

explanation.short: Bathrooms require 25 CFM continuous or 50 CFM intermittent exhaust when no operable window is present.
explanation.detailed: IMC Table 403.3 and IRC specify minimum ventilation rates. Bathrooms without openable windows require mechanical exhaust: 25 CFM continuous OR 50 CFM intermittent (controlled by occupant). For continuous operation, many codes now require it. ASHRAE 62.2 has similar requirements. Commercial toilet rooms have higher requirements based on fixtures or floor area.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance from an exhaust duct termination to an operable window?

choices.b: 3 feet

explanation.short: Exhaust outlets must be at least 3 feet from any operable window, door, or air intake.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 501.3.1 requires exhaust air outlets to terminate at least 3 feet from any openable window, door, outdoor air intake, or property line. This prevents contaminated exhaust from reentering the building. Higher hazard exhausts (kitchen, lab) may require greater distances. Also must be at least 10 feet from mechanical air intakes. Check local amendments.

questions.question: Per IMC, what is the minimum outdoor air requirement for a commercial office space?

choices.b: 15-20 CFM per person

explanation.short: Commercial offices require approximately 17-20 CFM outdoor air per person per IMC/ASHRAE 62.1.
explanation.detailed: IMC Table 403.3 (based on ASHRAE 62.1) requires outdoor air based on occupancy type. For offices: approximately 5 CFM/person + 0.06 CFM/sq ft area rate, typically totaling 15-20 CFM/person. This ensures adequate dilution of CO2 and pollutants. The exact rate depends on space type, occupant density, and whether the space allows smoking. DOAS and ERV systems help meet requirements efficiently.

questions.question: What is makeup air in relation to exhaust systems?

choices.b: Outdoor air introduced to replace air removed by exhaust

explanation.short: Makeup air is outdoor air intentionally introduced to replace air being exhausted from the building.
explanation.detailed: Exhaust systems remove air from buildings. Without replacing it, negative pressure develops, causing backdrafting of combustion appliances, door operation problems, and reduced exhaust effectiveness. Makeup air systems intentionally introduce outdoor air (often tempered or conditioned) to maintain neutral or slight positive pressure. Commercial kitchens and large exhaust systems require dedicated makeup air.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference makeup air requirements in IMC

questions.question: What is an air-side economizer used for?

choices.b: Use outdoor air for free cooling when conditions permit

explanation.short: Air-side economizers use cool outdoor air to reduce or eliminate mechanical cooling when outdoor conditions are favorable.
explanation.detailed: Economizers are damper systems that increase outdoor air intake when outdoor temperature/enthalpy is lower than return air. Instead of recirculating warm indoor air and using compressors to cool it, the system brings in cool outdoor air directly. Controls compare outdoor and return conditions, modulating dampers accordingly. Required by energy codes for commercial systems above certain tonnage. Significant energy savings in mild climates.

questions.question: What is the difference between an ERV and an HRV?

choices.a: ERV transfers only heat; HRV transfers heat and moisture
choices.b: ERV transfers both heat and moisture; HRV transfers only sensible heat
choices.d: ERV is for commercial; HRV is for residential only

explanation.short: ERV (Energy Recovery Ventilator) transfers heat and moisture; HRV (Heat Recovery Ventilator) transfers only sensible heat.
explanation.detailed: Both exchange energy between exhaust and supply air streams. HRV: sensible (temperature) exchange only via metal plates. ERV: total energy (sensible + latent) exchange using permeable membrane that transfers moisture. Choose based on climate: humid climates benefit from ERV (moisture transfer reduces load); cold dry climates may prefer HRV (retain indoor moisture in winter).

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance required between a duct and combustible material if the duct carries air above 250°F?

choices.b: 1 inch

explanation.short: Ducts carrying air above 250°F require minimum 6-inch clearance from combustibles.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 603.8 requires clearance from combustibles based on duct temperature. Air below 250°F: no clearance required (most HVAC). 250°F-450°F: 6-inch clearance. Above 450°F: 18-inch clearance. This applies primarily to industrial processes or heating system supply ducts near furnaces. Alternatively, approved shielding can reduce required clearances.

questions.question: When are access doors required in duct systems?

choices.b: At fire/smoke dampers and at intervals for cleaning

explanation.short: Access doors are required at fire/smoke dampers for inspection/reset and at appropriate intervals for system cleaning.
explanation.detailed: IMC requires access to: fire and smoke dampers (for inspection, testing, and reset); internal equipment (coils, fans, dampers); and duct systems for cleaning. NADCA recommends access at 12-foot intervals in main ducts. Access doors must match duct pressure class and maintain integrity. Planning access during design prevents costly retrofits.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a backdraft damper on an exhaust duct?

choices.b: Prevent reverse airflow when the exhaust fan is off

explanation.short: Backdraft dampers prevent outdoor air from entering through the exhaust duct when the fan is not running.
explanation.detailed: Exhaust ducts penetrate the building envelope. Without backdraft dampers, wind pressure or stack effect can push outdoor air into the building when the fan is off, causing energy loss and comfort issues. Backdraft dampers (gravity or spring-loaded) open when the fan runs (airflow pressure) and close when airflow stops. Common on bath fans, dryer vents, and range hoods.

questions.question: What is the function of a volume damper in a duct?

choices.b: Adjust airflow volume to a branch or zone

explanation.short: Volume dampers adjust airflow by creating a controlled restriction, used for balancing and zone control.
explanation.detailed: Volume dampers regulate airflow in duct branches. Types include: single blade (butterfly), opposed blade, parallel blade, and iris. Used for: initial air balancing (set once, lock in place), zone control (modulate with controls), and isolation (fully open/closed). Location should be accessible for adjustment. Single blade can cause turbulence; opposed blade provides more linear control.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference volume damper types and applications

questions.question: What characterizes a multizone air handling system?

choices.b: Mixing dampers at the AHU blend hot and cold air for each zone's supply duct

explanation.short: Multizone systems have hot and cold decks at the AHU with mixing dampers that blend air to each zone's required temperature.
explanation.detailed: True multizone systems have heating and cooling coils (hot deck and cold deck) at the air handler. Each zone has dedicated supply duct and mixing dampers that modulate to blend hot and cold air per zone thermostat. Not as efficient as VAV (mixing hot and cold wastes energy), but provides good zone control. Largely replaced by VAV in new construction but still found in existing buildings.

questions.question: What does a VAV box control?

choices.b: Airflow volume to a zone based on zone temperature

explanation.short: VAV (Variable Air Volume) boxes modulate airflow to zones based on thermostat demand.
explanation.detailed: VAV systems supply a constant temperature but vary volume. VAV boxes (terminal units) contain a modulating damper controlled by zone thermostat. When the zone is satisfied, damper closes to minimum; when the zone needs conditioning, damper opens fully. Some VAV boxes include reheat coils for heating mode. VFD-controlled supply fan responds to overall duct static pressure. More energy-efficient than CAV systems.

questions.question: What characterizes a constant air volume (CAV) system?

choices.b: Constant airflow, variable supply temperature

explanation.short: CAV systems maintain constant airflow volume while varying supply air temperature to meet load.
explanation.detailed: Constant Air Volume systems deliver the same CFM regardless of load. Temperature control is achieved by modulating heating/cooling at the air handler. Simple controls and ductwork but less efficient - moving design CFM even when load is low wastes fan energy. Most residential systems are CAV (cycling on/off). Commercial buildings prefer VAV for efficiency. Multi-zone CAV provides zone control.

questions.question: What is a ductulator used for?

choices.b: Quickly finding duct size based on CFM, friction, and velocity

explanation.short: A ductulator is a slide-rule calculator that quickly determines duct size from CFM, friction rate, and velocity.
explanation.detailed: Ductulators (or duct calculators) are circular slide rules with scales for CFM, duct size (round and rectangular equivalent), friction rate, and velocity. Align any two values to read the others. Available in manual and electronic versions. Faster than friction charts for field work. Still useful despite software because they work without power and show relationships between variables.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a supply plenum?

choices.b: Distribute air from the air handler to multiple trunk ducts

explanation.short: A supply plenum is a large chamber that receives air handler output and distributes it to multiple supply trunk ducts.
explanation.detailed: Plenums are large boxes or chambers that serve as transition points. Supply plenum connects air handler discharge to main supply ducts; return plenum connects return ducts to air handler intake. Plenums allow velocity reduction and more uniform pressure distribution before air enters the duct system. Size them for low velocity (< 800 FPM) to minimize losses and noise.

questions.question: When can a ceiling space be used as a return air plenum?

choices.b: When constructed properly with plenum-rated materials and no prohibited spaces

explanation.short: Ceiling plenums are permitted when materials have proper flame/smoke ratings and the space is separated from prohibited sources.
explanation.detailed: IMC allows ceiling spaces and raised floor spaces as return plenums if: all materials in the space are plenum-rated (low smoke, low flame spread per NFPA 90A); no prohibited spaces (bathrooms, kitchens, mechanical rooms) communicate with the plenum; and wiring is plenum-rated (CL2P, CL3P, CMP). This eliminates return ductwork cost. Common in commercial buildings with suspended ceilings.

questions.question: What special requirements apply to underground duct systems?

choices.b: Must be watertight, corrosion-resistant, and have provisions for drainage and access

explanation.short: Underground ducts must be watertight, resist corrosion, slope to drain, and provide access for inspection and cleaning.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 604 governs underground duct. Requirements: made from approved materials resistant to ground conditions (fiberglass, coated metal, or approved plastic); watertight joints sealed against groundwater; slope to low point with drain; access for inspection at every major change of direction or termination. Prevents water infiltration and mold. Common in slab-on-grade construction.

questions.question: What are the advantages of spiral round duct over longitudinal seam duct?

choices.b: Stronger, more airtight, and can use lighter gauge metal

explanation.short: Spiral duct is stronger (helical lock seam), more airtight, and requires lighter gauge metal than longitudinal seam.
explanation.detailed: Spiral duct has a continuous helical lock seam that adds strength (like corrugation). Benefits: use 24-26 gauge where snap lock would need 22-24; inherently airtight spiral seam reduces leakage; less likely to flex/oil-can; faster factory production. Disadvantage: must be factory-made (not field-fabricated), fittings require careful connection. Gasketed connections further reduce leakage.

questions.question: Which duct seam type is generally the most airtight?

choices.b: Pittsburgh seam

explanation.short: Welded seams and spiral lock seams are most airtight; mechanical seams require sealant.
explanation.detailed: Seam types ranked by inherent airtightness: welded (continuous, no gaps), spiral (helical lock with minimal gaps), Pittsburgh (folded and flattened, small gaps), snap lock (pressed together, moderate gaps), standing seam (upright fold, can gap). For typical HVAC, seal all seams with mastic or tape regardless of type to meet duct leakage requirements.

questions.question: According to NADCA, what determines when duct cleaning is needed?

choices.b: Visual inspection showing debris, mold, or vermin; or after construction/water damage

explanation.short: NADCA recommends cleaning based on visual inspection findings: debris buildup, mold, vermin, or after events like construction or water damage.
explanation.detailed: NADCA (National Air Duct Cleaners Association) doesn't specify fixed intervals. Clean when: visible debris accumulation in ducts; mold growth visible or confirmed by testing; vermin infestation; after construction/renovation (especially without protecting ducts); after water damage; or occupant health complaints potentially related to IAQ. Routine cleaning without cause has minimal benefit.

questions.question: Condensation is forming on the exterior of supply ducts in an attic. What is the MOST LIKELY cause?

choices.b: Insufficient insulation on cold supply ducts in humid attic air

explanation.short: Cold supply ducts in humid unconditioned spaces will sweat if insulation is inadequate to keep exterior surface above dew point.
explanation.detailed: During cooling, supply ducts are cold (typically 55°F). Attic air can be hot and humid. If duct surface temperature drops below dew point of attic air, condensation forms. Solutions: increase insulation R-value (R-8 minimum per code, more in humid climates), ensure vapor barrier is continuous and sealed, and reduce attic humidity if possible. Dripping water damages ceilings and promotes mold.

questions.question: Where should the vapor barrier be located on insulated supply ducts in cooling climates?

choices.a: On the inside (against the duct metal)
choices.b: On the outside of the insulation

explanation.short: Vapor barrier goes on the warm side (outside of insulation in cooling mode) to prevent moisture from reaching the cold duct surface.
explanation.detailed: Vapor barriers block moisture migration through insulation. For cold ducts in warm spaces (cooling mode), vapor barrier faces the warm (outdoor) side - outside of insulation. This prevents humid air from penetrating insulation and condensing on the cold duct. The barrier must be continuous; all joints and penetrations sealed. FSK (foil-scrim-kraft) facing on duct wrap provides vapor barrier.

questions.question: With 1200 CFM and a 20°F temperature rise across a furnace, what is the approximate heating output?

choices.b: 26,000 BTU/hr

explanation.short: Sensible heat formula: BTU/hr = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT = 1.08 × 1200 × 20 = 25,920 BTU/hr ≈ 26,000.
explanation.detailed: The sensible heat equation for air is Q = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT, where Q is BTU/hr and ΔT is temperature change in °F. The constant 1.08 accounts for air density and specific heat at standard conditions. Calculate: 1.08 × 1200 × 20 = 25,920 BTU/hr, approximately 26,000. This formula is fundamental for HVAC calculations - verify airflow and temperature rise during commissioning.
explanation.how_to_find: Use sensible heat formula: Q = 1.08 × CFM × ΔT

questions.question: What is the typical temperature rise across a gas furnace?

explanation.short: Gas furnaces typically have a 30-60°F temperature rise, verified by manufacturer's specifications.
explanation.detailed: Temperature rise is measured from return air entering to supply air leaving the furnace. Each furnace has a rated rise range (e.g., 35-65°F) on the nameplate. Too low rise indicates excess airflow or low firing rate; too high indicates insufficient airflow. Measure with thermometers in supply and return plenums. Always verify against manufacturer's specifications.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference furnace nameplate temperature rise range

questions.question: What is the typical temperature drop across an air conditioning evaporator?

explanation.short: A/C systems typically produce 16-22°F temperature drop across the evaporator at 400 CFM/ton.
explanation.detailed: Air passing through a properly operating evaporator coil drops 16-22°F (sometimes specified as 18-20°F). Lower ΔT may indicate: high airflow, restricted refrigerant, low charge. Higher ΔT may indicate: low airflow, dirty filter/coil, oversized system. Measure in supply plenum and return plenum, not at distant registers which are affected by duct gains.

questions.question: What is the typical design allowance for heat gain through supply ducts in unconditioned spaces?

choices.b: 3-5% of sensible cooling load

explanation.short: Design typically allows 10-15% additional capacity for duct gains when ducts pass through unconditioned spaces.
explanation.detailed: Even insulated ducts gain heat from hot attics or lose heat to cold spaces. Manual J load calculations include duct loss/gain factors, typically adding 10-15% to sensible load when ducts are in unconditioned spaces (varies by location and insulation level). Ducts in conditioned space have minimal loss. This factor sizes equipment to overcome duct losses and still deliver design conditions to rooms.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference duct gain factors in Manual J

questions.question: A system has high external static pressure and low airflow. What is the MOST LIKELY cause?

choices.b: Restrictive filter, undersized ducts, or closed dampers

explanation.short: High static with low airflow indicates restriction: dirty/restrictive filter, undersized ducts, collapsed flex, or closed dampers.
explanation.detailed: Static pressure is the blower pushing against resistance. High static means high resistance somewhere. Common causes: dirty filter (most common), undersized ducts, kinked/crushed flex duct, too many closed registers, dampers inadvertently closed, iced evaporator coil. Systematically check each possibility. Measure static pressure at multiple points to locate the restriction.

questions.question: How is available static pressure typically split between supply and return systems?

choices.b: 60% supply, 40% return

explanation.short: Manual D recommends approximately 60% of available static for supply system and 40% for return.
explanation.detailed: After deducting filter, coil, and accessory losses from equipment-rated TESP, the remaining pressure must be split between supply and return duct systems. Typical split: 60% supply, 40% return. Rationale: supply systems are usually longer and more complex with multiple outlets. Adjust based on actual design - long return runs may need more pressure allocation.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual D static pressure budget

questions.question: Available static for supply is 0.15 in. w.c. The longest supply run has 150 ft total effective length. What is the design friction rate?

explanation.short: Friction rate = Available static ÷ (Total effective length ÷ 100) = 0.15 ÷ 1.5 = 0.10 in. w.c./100 ft.
explanation.detailed: Manual D friction rate calculation: Divide available static by total effective length in hundreds of feet. TEL = 150 ft = 1.5 × 100 ft. Friction rate = 0.15 ÷ 1.5 = 0.10 in. w.c./100 ft. Use this friction rate with a friction chart or ductulator to size all supply ducts. All runs shorter than critical path will have lower actual friction rate (excess capacity).

questions.question: What is a register boot in duct systems?

choices.b: A transition fitting from round or rectangular duct to register/grille opening

explanation.short: A boot is a sheet metal fitting that transitions from duct to the register or grille size and shape.
explanation.detailed: Boots (also called transition boots or register boxes) connect branch ducts to supply registers or return grilles. Common types: straight boot (duct directly below register), angled boot (duct offset from register), universal boot (multiple inlet options). Boots add pressure drop that must be accounted for in equivalent lengths. Quality boots have smooth transitions; poor boots cause turbulence and noise.

questions.question: What is a stack head or stack boot used for?

choices.b: Transitioning from a wall stack duct to a floor or ceiling register

explanation.short: Stack heads connect vertical wall stack ducts to horizontal registers in floors or ceilings.
explanation.detailed: Wall stacks are narrow rectangular ducts that run inside wall cavities (typically 3.5 inch deep for 2x4 walls). Stack heads (at top) and stack boots (at bottom) transition from the narrow rectangular stack to floor or ceiling register openings. This allows supply or return air routing through walls without visible ductwork. Common in multi-story homes.

questions.question: What is a panned joist return?

choices.b: A return air path created by enclosing floor joist cavities with sheet metal panning

explanation.short: Panned joist returns use sheet metal nailed to floor joists to create return air pathways using the joist cavity.
explanation.detailed: Panned returns enclose the bottom of floor joist bays with sheet metal, using the joist cavity as a return duct. Cost-effective but problematic: difficult to seal (leaky), can draw dusty/contaminated air from wall cavities, and may not meet current energy codes for duct leakage. Many jurisdictions now prohibit or limit panned returns. Sealed duct systems are preferred.

questions.question: A customer complains of whistling noise at one register. What is the MOST LIKELY cause?

choices.b: High velocity through that register or restrictive grille

explanation.short: Whistling at a single register usually indicates excessive velocity through that outlet or restriction at the grille.
explanation.detailed: Whistling noise is caused by high-velocity air passing through a restriction. At a single register: partially closed damper, undersized register for the CFM, or debris/obstruction in the boot. Solutions: open damper, increase register size, verify CFM is appropriate for register rating, or check for obstructions. If all registers whistle, the entire system may have high velocity or pressure.

questions.question: Loud popping or banging noises occur in ductwork when the system starts. What causes this?

choices.b: Thermal expansion/contraction of sheet metal or oil-canning

explanation.short: Popping or banging is typically oil-canning - thin sheet metal flexing as pressure or temperature changes.
explanation.detailed: Oil-canning occurs when flat duct surfaces flex abruptly between two stable positions as pressure changes at startup/shutdown. Causes: ducts made from thin gauge metal; large flat surfaces without reinforcement; high pressure differential. Solutions: add cross-breaking or beading to stiffen flat panels; install tie rods; use heavier gauge metal. Temperature changes also cause expansion/contraction noise at joints.

questions.question: What is the purpose of cross-breaking rectangular duct panels?

choices.b: Stiffen the panel to prevent oil-canning and noise

explanation.short: Cross-breaking creates angled creases across duct panels to stiffen them and prevent flexing (oil-canning).
explanation.detailed: Flat sheet metal is flexible and prone to oil-canning (sudden popping between positions). Cross-breaking creates diagonal creases that add rigidity like a corrugation. Standard on larger rectangular ducts per SMACNA. Alternatives: beading (rolled ridges), tie rods between opposite sides. Duct fabrication machines typically include cross-breaking capabilities. Critical for quiet operation.

questions.question: When performing a pitot traverse, how many readings are typically required in a round duct?

choices.b: 2-4 readings
choices.c: Multiple readings at specified radii on at least 2 diameters (typically 20 points)

explanation.short: Pitot traverses require multiple readings at specific radii on two or more perpendicular diameters, typically 20 or more points.
explanation.detailed: Air velocity varies across a duct cross-section (higher in center, lower near walls). A traverse samples multiple points and averages them. Log-Tchebycheff or equal-area methods specify exact positions. For round ducts, sample on two perpendicular diameters at points located at specific radii. Typically 10 points per diameter = 20 total. This gives accurate average velocity for CFM calculation.

questions.question: What is the ideal location for a pitot tube traverse in a duct?

choices.b: At least 7.5 duct diameters downstream of a disturbance

explanation.short: Traverse should be 7.5 diameters downstream and 3 diameters upstream of any disturbance for uniform velocity profile.
explanation.detailed: Fittings (elbows, transitions, dampers) create non-uniform velocity profiles. Accurate traversing requires developed flow. Ideal: 7.5 diameters of straight duct downstream and 3 diameters upstream of the test location. If impossible, use correction factors or alternative methods. Fewer diameters means less accurate readings due to swirl and uneven velocity.

questions.question: What is 'system effect' in fan performance?

choices.b: Additional pressure loss due to non-ideal inlet or outlet conditions

explanation.short: System effect is additional pressure loss beyond rated performance due to poor inlet/outlet connections that disrupt airflow.
explanation.detailed: Fans are rated with ideal inlet and outlet conditions. Real installations have elbows, transitions, or obstructions near fan connections that disrupt airflow. This causes additional pressure loss not shown on fan curves - the 'system effect.' AMCA publishes system effect factors. Poor installations can lose 10-30% of fan performance. Provide straight duct (2-3 diameters minimum) at fan connections when possible.

questions.question: What does TAB stand for in HVAC commissioning?

choices.b: Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing

explanation.short: TAB is Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing - the process of verifying and optimizing HVAC system performance.
explanation.detailed: TAB is performed after installation to verify systems meet design intent. Testing: measure airflows, pressures, temperatures. Adjusting: set damper positions, fan speeds, control setpoints. Balancing: adjust airflows to achieve design CFM at each outlet. TAB is performed by certified technicians (NEBB, AABC, TABB). A TAB report documents all measurements and adjustments.

questions.question: What is proportional balancing?

choices.a: Adjusting each outlet to exact design CFM
choices.b: Adjusting outlets proportionally so percent of design is equal across all outlets

explanation.short: Proportional balancing adjusts all outlets to the same percentage of design airflow, even if total system airflow differs from design.
explanation.detailed: If total system airflow doesn't match design (common), proportional balancing adjusts each outlet to deliver the same percentage of its design CFM. Example: if total system is 90% of design, each outlet is adjusted to 90% of its design. This maintains relative distribution even when total airflow is off. The alternative (setting each outlet to exact design CFM) requires correcting total airflow first.

questions.question: What is the recommended maximum length for flexible duct runouts from trunk to register?

choices.b: 15-25 feet depending on design

explanation.short: Flex duct runs should typically be limited to 15-25 feet maximum, fully stretched, for residential systems.
explanation.detailed: While there's no absolute code limit, best practice limits flex duct runs to maintain performance. Flex duct has higher friction than metal, and long runs with bends add significant pressure drop. Manual D recommends keeping flex runs short and straight. Many designers limit to 15-25 feet. Exceeding this without accounting for it in design causes underperforming outlets. Always stretch flex taut.

questions.question: When installing a reducing trunk, the reduction should be on which side?

choices.b: Bottom only for gravity drainage
choices.c: One side only to maintain bottom alignment for condensate drainage

explanation.short: Reduce from top and one side to maintain bottom alignment for proper condensate drainage in cooling mode.
explanation.detailed: Supply ducts in cooling mode may have condensate form on interior surfaces. If the duct bottom maintains consistent elevation (no steps up), water drains toward the air handler for collection. Reducing from bottom creates low spots that pool water. Best practice: reduce from top and sides, keeping bottom flat. Similarly, transitions should have smooth bottom transitions.

questions.question: What is the proper way to connect flex duct to a metal collar?

choices.b: Slip over collar, mechanically fasten with clamp, then seal with mastic or approved tape

explanation.short: Flex duct must slip over the collar at least 2 inches, be secured with a draw band or clamp, and sealed with mastic or UL 181B tape.
explanation.detailed: Proper flex duct connection: (1) Pull flex over collar minimum 2 inches; (2) Secure inner liner with draw band or clamp; (3) Extend outer vapor barrier/jacket over connection; (4) Secure outer jacket with second clamp; (5) Seal all connections with mastic or UL 181B-listed tape. This prevents pullout and air leakage.

questions.question: What is the purpose of S-slips and drive cleats in rectangular duct assembly?

choices.b: Connecting transverse joints between duct sections

explanation.short: S-slips connect the long sides and drive cleats connect the short sides of rectangular duct transverse joints.
explanation.detailed: Rectangular duct sections are joined at transverse (across-duct) joints. S-slips slide into folded edges on both duct sections (long sides). Drive cleats fold over the remaining edges (short sides) and are hammered on. Together they create a mechanical joint that is then sealed. Standard for low-pressure residential and commercial duct.

questions.question: When are flanged duct connections typically used?

choices.b: Medium and high-pressure systems requiring more robust, serviceable connections

explanation.short: Flanged (TDC, TDF) connections are used for medium/high-pressure systems where stronger, gasketed joints are needed.
explanation.detailed: Transverse Duct Connector (TDC) and Transverse Duct Flange (TDF) are formed flanges with bolt holes. Duct sections are gasketed and bolted together. Benefits: stronger than slip-and-drive; can be disassembled for service; gasketed for better sealing; required for higher pressure classes. Cost more but essential for 3+ in. w.c. systems. Common in commercial/industrial.

questions.question: What is the most efficient way to offset a duct around an obstruction?

choices.b: Two 45° elbows with straight section between

explanation.short: Two 45° elbows with a straight section create the lowest pressure drop offset.
explanation.detailed: Offsets must route around obstructions while minimizing loss. Options ranked by pressure drop: Two 45° elbows (lowest loss); two long-radius 90° elbows; square offset box with turning vanes; two short-radius 90° elbows (highest loss). A straight section between the elbows allows airflow to recover between turns. Avoid using flex as an offset - it's high friction and often sags.

questions.question: When is a wye (Y) fitting preferred over a tee for duct branching?

choices.b: When lower pressure loss is needed and space permits angled branches

explanation.short: Wye fittings have lower pressure loss than tees because airflow turns through a shallower angle.
explanation.detailed: Tees create 90° turns into branches; wyes use 30-45° angled branches. The shallower angle means less abrupt direction change and lower pressure loss. Wyes are preferred where space allows. However, they take more room than tees. Conical wyes are best. Bullhead tees (equal-size branches opposite each other) have very high losses and should be avoided.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference wye vs tee fitting losses

questions.question: Why should bullhead tee fittings be avoided in duct design?

choices.b: They cause high turbulence and pressure loss when airflow splits 180°

explanation.short: Bullhead tees force air to turn 90° in opposite directions, causing high turbulence and pressure loss.
explanation.detailed: A bullhead tee has one inlet and two outlets directly opposite each other (like a T on its side). Air entering the main must split and turn 90° both ways simultaneously, creating severe turbulence. Pressure drop is very high - often 50+ ft equivalent length. Better alternatives: supply from one end, or use a wye or diverging tee that maintains airflow direction before branching.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference bullhead tee in Manual D equivalent lengths

questions.question: When can fire-rated duct wrap be used instead of a fire damper?

choices.b: When ducts pass through fire-rated assemblies but dampers are not required by code

explanation.short: Fire-rated wrap maintains fire rating of the duct penetration where dampers aren't required but fire rating must be preserved.
explanation.detailed: Some fire-rated assembly penetrations don't require dampers (per IMC exceptions) but still need fire-resistance continuity. Fire-rated duct wrap (mineral fiber enclosure) provides the required fire rating around the duct. It's an alternative to running duct through rated shaft or installing dampers. Must be installed per manufacturer's listing for the specific fire-rating duration.

questions.question: What restriction applies to ducts passing through corridors in commercial buildings?

choices.b: Must be enclosed or have smoke dampers at corridor boundaries

explanation.short: Ducts passing through corridors typically require enclosure or smoke/fire dampers to prevent corridor contamination.
explanation.detailed: Corridors are exit pathways requiring protection from smoke. Ducts passing through them (or drawing air from them) can spread smoke in fires. IMC and IBC require: (1) Ducts enclosed in rated construction, or (2) Smoke dampers at corridor boundaries, or (3) Smoke detection-controlled HVAC shutdown. Specifics depend on building type, corridor fire rating, and HVAC system design.

questions.question: What is the minimum intermittent exhaust rate for a residential kitchen?

choices.b: 50 CFM

explanation.short: Residential kitchens require minimum 100 CFM intermittent or 25 CFM continuous exhaust ventilation.
explanation.detailed: IMC Table 403.3 specifies kitchen ventilation: 100 CFM intermittent (controlled by occupant) or 25 CFM continuous. Range hoods typically meet this with 150-400+ CFM. Ductless recirculating hoods don't count as exhaust. ASHRAE 62.2 has similar requirements. Commercial kitchens have much higher requirements based on hood type and cooking equipment.

questions.question: What is required when installing metal ducts in or under a concrete slab?

choices.b: Corrosion protection and drainage provisions

explanation.short: In-slab metal ducts require corrosion-resistant coating and provisions for drainage and access.
explanation.detailed: Metal ducts in or below slabs are exposed to moisture and soil. IMC Section 604 requires: corrosion-resistant material or coating (galvanizing alone may not be sufficient - additional coating often needed); slope to drain to accessible low point; access for inspection at changes of direction. Alternative: factory-made products designed for below-grade installation.

questions.question: What is the typical thickness of acoustical duct liner?

choices.b: 1/2 to 2 inches

explanation.short: Acoustical duct liner is typically 1/2 to 2 inches thick depending on noise reduction requirements.
explanation.detailed: Thicker liner = more sound absorption, especially at low frequencies. Common thicknesses: 1/2 inch (minimum practical); 1 inch (typical commercial); 2 inches (high attenuation needs). Thicker liner reduces duct area (account in sizing) and adds cost. Liner must be secured to duct and have appropriate facing to prevent fiber release. Select thickness based on NC requirements.

questions.question: What is the maximum recommended main duct velocity for commercial systems with NC-35 requirement?

choices.b: 1200 FPM

explanation.short: For NC-35 (typical office), main duct velocity should not exceed approximately 1200-1500 FPM.
explanation.detailed: Velocity recommendations depend on acoustic requirements. Lower NC targets require lower velocities. Typical guidelines for main ducts: NC-25 (studios): 600-800 FPM; NC-35 (offices): 1000-1500 FPM; NC-45 (retail): 1500-2000 FPM. Branch ducts near outlets should be lower. Always check specific project requirements and equipment manufacturer data.

questions.question: A 100 sq ft bathroom requires 1 CFM per sq ft exhaust. What minimum fan size is needed?

choices.b: 80 CFM

explanation.short: 100 sq ft × 1 CFM/sq ft = 100 CFM minimum.
explanation.detailed: Some codes use CFM per square foot for bathroom sizing (in addition to or instead of fixture-based minimums). Calculation: 100 sq ft × 1 CFM/sq ft = 100 CFM. This also meets the 50 CFM intermittent minimum for bathrooms. Select a fan with rated CFM at the expected static pressure (duct length affects this). Fans are often rated at 0.1 in. w.c. but may deliver less with longer ducts.

questions.question: Can multiple bathroom exhaust fans connect to a common exhaust duct?

choices.b: Yes, with backdraft dampers on each branch and proper sizing

explanation.short: Multiple exhaust fans can share a duct if each has backdraft dampers and the common duct is sized for total airflow.
explanation.detailed: IMC allows combining exhaust from similar sources (multiple bathrooms) into a common duct. Requirements: backdraft dampers on each branch to prevent air from entering inactive exhaust paths; common duct sized for total connected CFM; each fan maintains rated performance. An alternative is a central exhaust fan with branches to multiple bathrooms.

questions.question: What is an advantage of an inline exhaust fan versus a ceiling-mounted fan?

choices.b: Quieter operation in the room because fan is located remotely in duct

explanation.short: Inline fans install in the duct away from the room, so fan noise is remote and the room is quieter.
explanation.detailed: Inline (remote) fans mount in the attic or other location away from the occupied space. Only the grille is in the room. Benefits: quieter operation in the room; can serve multiple grilles; higher CFM options available. Drawbacks: harder to access for service; must be supported properly; duct on both inlet and outlet.

questions.question: What does a fan curve show?

choices.b: Relationship between airflow (CFM) and static pressure

explanation.short: A fan curve graphs airflow (CFM) on the X-axis against static pressure on the Y-axis, showing fan performance.
explanation.detailed: Fan performance curves show how airflow decreases as static pressure (resistance) increases. At zero static pressure, fan delivers maximum CFM. At shutoff (maximum static), flow is zero. Operating point is where the fan curve intersects the system curve. Fan selection matches the curve to design CFM and static pressure. Also shows brake horsepower and efficiency at various operating points.

questions.question: What is the relationship between airflow and pressure drop in a duct system (system curve)?

choices.a: Linear - double CFM doubles pressure drop
choices.b: Squared - double CFM quadruples pressure drop
choices.c: Inverse - higher CFM means lower pressure drop

explanation.short: Pressure drop varies with the square of airflow - doubling CFM quadruples pressure drop.
explanation.detailed: The fan law relationship: ΔP is proportional to CFM². A system with 0.5 in. w.c. at 1000 CFM would have 2.0 in. w.c. at 2000 CFM (4× pressure). This parabolic relationship is the system curve. When plotted against a fan curve, the intersection is the operating point.
