Changing system resistance (filter loading, damper position) shifts the system curve, changing the operating point.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference fan laws and system curves

questions.question: A fan delivers 1000 CFM at 1000 RPM. What CFM will it deliver at 1200 RPM?

choices.b: 1100 CFM

explanation.short: CFM varies directly with RPM: CFM₂ = CFM₁ × (RPM₂/RPM₁) = 1000 × (1200/1000) = 1200 CFM.
explanation.detailed: Fan Laws describe relationships: (1) CFM varies directly with speed - CFM₂/CFM₁ = RPM₂/RPM₁; (2) Pressure varies with speed squared; (3) Power varies with speed cubed. Calculate: 1000 × (1200/1000) = 1000 × 1.2 = 1200 CFM. Note: pressure would increase to (1.2)² = 1.44× and power to (1.2)³ = 1.73× original.

questions.question: Which fan type is most common for HVAC air handling applications?

choices.b: Forward-curved centrifugal fan

explanation.short: Forward-curved centrifugal (squirrel cage) fans are most common in HVAC for their quiet operation and broad operating range.
explanation.detailed: Fan types by application: Forward-curved centrifugal = most common for HVAC, quiet, efficient at moderate pressure; Backward-inclined centrifugal = higher efficiency, non-overloading, used in large systems; Propeller = low pressure, high volume (cooling towers, condensers); Vaneaxial = compact, high pressure/volume (commercial/industrial). Forward-curved is the 'squirrel cage' blower in most residential equipment.

questions.question: What is an ECM blower motor?

choices.b: Electronically commutated motor - a high-efficiency variable-speed DC motor

explanation.short: ECM (Electronically Commutated Motor) is a brushless DC motor with built-in electronics for variable speed and high efficiency.
explanation.detailed: ECM motors use permanent magnets and electronic commutation instead of brushes. Benefits: 70%+ efficiency (vs 40-60% for PSC motors); variable speed capability; maintains CFM as filter loads; quieter at low speeds. The motor controller constantly adjusts to maintain programmed airflow. Standard in high-efficiency equipment. Costs more but saves energy over system life.

questions.question: What is the cross-sectional area of a 10-inch round duct?

choices.b: 78.5 sq in

explanation.short: Area = π × r² = 3.14 × 5² = 78.5 sq in.
explanation.detailed: For circular ducts: Area = π × radius². Diameter = 10 in, so radius = 5 in. Area = 3.14159 × 5² = 3.14159 × 25 = 78.5 sq in. To convert to square feet: 78.5 ÷ 144 = 0.545 sq ft. This area is used with velocity to calculate CFM: CFM = Area (sq ft) × Velocity (FPM).

questions.question: What is the cross-sectional area of a 12×8 inch rectangular duct?

choices.b: 48 sq in

explanation.short: Area = Width × Height = 12 × 8 = 96 sq in.
explanation.detailed: For rectangular ducts: Area = Width × Height. 12 × 8 = 96 sq in. Convert to sq ft: 96 ÷ 144 = 0.667 sq ft. This area, combined with velocity, gives CFM. Note that equivalent round diameter would be approximately 11 inches (not the average of dimensions).

questions.question: How is required CFM for each room determined in residential design?

choices.b: From Manual J room-by-room load calculations

explanation.short: Room CFM is derived from Manual J heating and cooling loads divided by system supply air temperature differential.
explanation.detailed: Manual D determines room CFM from Manual J loads. Process: (1) Manual J calculates BTU load for each room; (2) Divide room load by system temperature difference and heat constant (1.08) to get CFM. Example: 3000 BTU/hr cooling ÷ (1.08 × 20°F ΔT) = 139 CFM. Room CFM values then drive duct and register sizing. Don't use rules of thumb - calculate actual loads.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Manual D room airflow calculation

questions.question: What is a thermal break in duct installation?

choices.b: Insulation or isolation to prevent thermal bridging through supports or penetrations

explanation.short: Thermal breaks prevent conductive heat transfer through duct supports or envelope penetrations.
explanation.detailed: Metal duct supports passing through insulation create thermal bridges - pathways for heat to bypass insulation. Thermal breaks (insulating materials between duct and support, or non-metallic supports) prevent this. Also important at envelope penetrations - duct insulation must be continuous through the penetration. Thermal bridging reduces effective R-value and can cause condensation.

questions.question: Where is the most efficient location for duct systems?

choices.b: Crawlspace

explanation.short: Ducts inside conditioned space have minimal thermal losses and don't require as much insulation.
explanation.detailed: Ducts in conditioned space (interior walls, dropped ceilings, conditioned basements) have minimal temperature difference from surrounding air, so losses are minimal. Ducts in unconditioned spaces (attics, vented crawlspaces) can lose 10-30% of capacity to duct gains. Modern building science encourages bringing ducts inside the envelope - basement ducts, interior chase-ways, or conditioned attics.

questions.question: A room requires 150 CFM. A 6×12 register is rated for 125 CFM at 0.03 in. w.c. Is this register adequate?

choices.b: No, it's undersized and will be noisy or restrictive
choices.c: Yes, registers always have extra capacity

explanation.short: The register is undersized. At 150 CFM it will exceed rated velocity, causing noise and high pressure drop.
explanation.detailed: Registers should be sized so required CFM is at or below rated capacity at acceptable NC. A register rated 125 CFM would need to pass 150 CFM (120% of rating), meaning velocity 20% higher than rated. This increases noise (potentially above acceptable NC) and pressure drop. Select a larger register or add a second register to serve the room properly.
explanation.how_to_find: Compare required CFM to register ratings

questions.question: What is an adjustable elbow used for?

choices.b: Field adjustment of angle when exact routing isn't known during fabrication

explanation.short: Adjustable elbows can be set to various angles in the field, accommodating unknown or variable routing conditions.
explanation.detailed: Adjustable (also called field-adjustable or multi-angle) elbows have sections that can be positioned from 0° to 90° (or more). Useful when: exact offset isn't known until installation; connecting to misaligned ducts; avoiding field fabrication of custom angles. Once positioned, they're secured. Slightly higher friction than smooth fixed elbows due to more joints.

questions.question: What is a spin-in fitting?

choices.b: A branch takeoff collar that twists into a hole cut in the trunk duct

explanation.short: A spin-in is a branch takeoff collar with tabs that insert into a hole cut in the trunk and twist to lock in place.
explanation.detailed: Spin-in fittings (also called tap-in or self-tapping start collars) have a crimped end with bent tabs. A hole is cut in the trunk duct, the spin-in is inserted, and twisted to lock the tabs against the duct wall. Fast field installation without fabricating a proper takeoff fitting. Should be sealed with mastic. Available with or without dampers.

questions.question: What is a starting collar?

choices.b: A collar that connects round duct or flex to a plenum or duct board opening

explanation.short: A starting collar provides a round connection point at a plenum or duct board for attaching round duct or flex.
explanation.detailed: Starting collars (also called start collars or spin-ins) provide a transition from flat surfaces (plenums, duct board) to round duct. They have a flange or tabs for attachment to the plenum and a crimped end for slip connection to round duct or flex. Available with integral dampers. Proper sealing at the connection is essential.

questions.question: What is a duct end cap used for?

choices.b: Terminating (closing off) the end of a duct run

explanation.short: End caps close off the end of trunk ducts where no further outlets are needed.
explanation.detailed: End caps (also called dead ends or caps) seal the terminal end of a duct run. Available flat (lowest loss for reducing trunk) or domed (for dead-end plenum style). Should be sealed like any other duct joint. On extended plenum systems, the end cap terminates the trunk after the last takeoff. Removable end caps can provide future expansion capability.

questions.question: What is the preferred position for branch takeoffs from a supply trunk?

choices.b: Top or side of trunk

explanation.short: Takeoffs from top or side are preferred; bottom takeoffs can trap debris and are harder to serve with airflow.
explanation.detailed: Top and side takeoffs: airflow naturally diverts into branches; debris falls past rather than into branches. Bottom takeoffs: harder for air to turn downward against momentum; collect debris; can trap condensation in cooling. If bottom takeoff is required (serving floor registers), use turning scoops or angled takeoffs. Always position takeoffs where trunk airflow can smoothly enter the branch.

questions.question: What is a turning scoop used for?

choices.b: Directing air from the trunk into a branch takeoff

explanation.short: Turning scoops are curved vanes inside the trunk that direct airflow into branch takeoffs.
explanation.detailed: A scoop (or turning diverter) is a curved vane inside the trunk at a takeoff location. It catches trunk airflow and redirects it into the branch. Particularly useful for takeoffs near the end of the trunk or in directions opposing trunk flow. Reduces pressure drop compared to unassisted 90° turns into branches. Can be factory-installed or field-added.

questions.question: What is the advantage of an opposed blade damper versus a parallel blade damper?

choices.b: More linear airflow control through the damper travel range

explanation.short: Opposed blade dampers provide more linear (proportional) airflow control compared to parallel blade.
explanation.detailed: Parallel blade dampers have all blades rotating the same direction - airflow diverts to one side as damper closes, then drops rapidly near closure. Non-linear control. Opposed blade dampers have adjacent blades rotating opposite directions - air splits more evenly, providing more gradual, linear reduction through the modulating range. Preferred for VAV and modulating applications. Parallel is acceptable for two-position (open/closed).

questions.question: What is a barometric bypass damper used for in zoning systems?

choices.b: Automatically open to relieve pressure when zone dampers close

explanation.short: Barometric bypass dampers automatically open when static pressure rises as zone dampers close, relieving excess pressure.
explanation.detailed: When zone dampers close in zoned systems, pressure builds. A barometric damper is weighted or spring-loaded to open at a set pressure (typically 0.5-0.7 in. w.c.). It bypasses excess supply air back to return, preventing high static damage to equipment and noise. Adjustable counterweight sets the opening pressure. An alternative to motorized bypass or variable-speed fan control.

questions.question: What tool is specifically designed for cutting duct board?

choices.b: Duct board knife with angled blade for shiplap cuts

explanation.short: Duct board knives have specialized blades that cut at an angle to create shiplap joints for proper assembly.
explanation.detailed: Duct board is fabricated by cutting and folding. Duct board knives have: long blade for cutting through thick material; angled blade tip to undercut edges for shiplap (overlapping) joints; scoring blade for folding. Proper shiplap joints ensure good air seal when taped. Straight cuts (with regular knife) leave gaps. Also need V-groove cutters for female folds.

questions.question: Why is cloth-backed duct tape NOT approved for sealing HVAC duct joints?

choices.b: The adhesive fails due to temperature cycling and age, causing tape to fall off

explanation.short: Cloth duct tape adhesive degrades with heat cycling and time, causing it to fail and fall off within months to years.
explanation.detailed: Despite its name, cloth 'duct tape' is NOT for ducts. The rubber-based adhesive fails due to: temperature cycling in attics/unconditioned spaces; UV exposure; and simple aging. Studies show it peels off within 1-2 years. UL 181-listed tapes (aluminum foil with appropriate adhesive) and mastic are proven to last the life of the system. Code requires listed products.

questions.question: What is the proper technique for applying mastic to duct joints?

choices.b: Apply thick coat bridging the joint, with fiberglass mesh tape on gaps over 1/8 inch
choices.d: Mastic is only for flex duct

explanation.short: Apply mastic thickly enough to bridge the joint; use fiberglass mesh tape for gaps larger than 1/8 inch.
explanation.detailed: Proper mastic application: (1) Clean surfaces of oil and dust; (2) Apply mastic with brush, gloved hand, or caulk gun; (3) Minimum 1/16 inch thick covering joint by 1 inch on each side; (4) For gaps > 1/8 inch, embed fiberglass mesh tape in mastic; (5) Allow to dry completely before system operation. Water-based mastic should not be applied in freezing conditions. Creates permanent, flexible seal.

questions.question: What is Aeroseal duct sealing technology?

choices.b: An interior spray sealant that seals leaks from inside the duct system

explanation.short: Aeroseal is a patented process that seals duct leaks from the inside by injecting aerosolized sealant particles.
explanation.detailed: Aeroseal technology: temporarily seal all registers; pressurize the duct system; inject atomized sealant particles that accumulate at leak points. Particles build up and seal holes from inside - works on leaks up to 5/8 inch. Computer monitors the process and verifies sealing. Can reduce leakage by 90%+. Effective for existing systems that are difficult to access for manual sealing.

questions.question: Where should static pressure be measured to determine filter pressure drop?

choices.b: Before the filter and after the filter, calculating the difference

explanation.short: Filter pressure drop is the difference between static pressure readings taken upstream and downstream of the filter.
explanation.detailed: To measure any component's pressure drop: take static pressure readings on each side of the component and subtract. For filters: measure in the return just before the filter box; measure just after the filter box (or in the blower compartment). Difference = filter drop. A clean filter might be 0.10 in. w.c.; dirty could be 0.40+ in. w.c. Same principle applies to coils, dampers, etc.

questions.question: What is the relationship between total pressure, static pressure, and velocity pressure?

choices.b: Total = Static + Velocity

explanation.short: Total Pressure = Static Pressure + Velocity Pressure (TP = SP + VP).
explanation.detailed: Total pressure is the sum of static (pushing on duct walls) and velocity (kinetic energy of moving air) pressures. This is Bernoulli's principle applied to HVAC. In a duct, total pressure decreases due to friction. Static and velocity can convert back and forth: velocity drops through an enlargement, but static rises (minus losses). Fan total pressure equals the total pressure rise across the fan.

questions.question: What is static regain in duct design?

choices.b: Conversion of velocity pressure to static pressure when velocity decreases

explanation.short: Static regain is the increase in static pressure when velocity decreases, such as after air is removed at a branch.
explanation.detailed: Per Bernoulli's principle, when velocity decreases (through enlargement or after air is removed by branches), some velocity pressure converts to static pressure - this is static regain. In large commercial systems, static regain design intentionally sizes downstream ducts to recover velocity pressure, maintaining static pressure further down the trunk. More complex than equal friction method but can reduce fan energy.

questions.question: What is load diversity in HVAC system design?

choices.b: Recognition that not all zones peak simultaneously, allowing smaller central equipment

explanation.short: Load diversity acknowledges that all zones don't peak at the same time, allowing central equipment to be sized smaller than the sum of zone peaks.
explanation.detailed: In multi-zone buildings, different zones peak at different times (east zones peak in morning sun, west in afternoon). If you sum all zone peaks, you oversize central equipment. Diversity factors (0.7-0.9 typically) reduce the sum to reflect simultaneous peak. Reduces equipment cost and improves part-load efficiency. Block load calculations properly account for diversity.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference diversity factors in commercial design

questions.question: When are duct smoke detectors required?

choices.b: Systems over 2000 CFM serving multiple floors or areas in commercial buildings

explanation.short: Duct smoke detectors are required for systems over 2000 CFM in commercial buildings per IMC, with specific placement requirements.
explanation.detailed: IMC Section 606 requires duct smoke detectors on systems with capacity over 2000 CFM. Location requirements include downstream of filters in supply ducts and in return ducts. When smoke is detected, the HVAC system shuts down to prevent spreading smoke. Detectors must be accessible for testing and maintenance. Local codes may have additional or different requirements.

questions.question: In proportional balancing, which outlets should be adjusted first?

choices.b: Outlets with lowest airflow (furthest from design or near the end of runs)

explanation.short: Start with outlets having the lowest percentage of design airflow, typically the furthest runs.
explanation.detailed: Proportional balancing procedure: (1) Measure all outlets and calculate percent of design; (2) Start with the outlet having lowest percentage and open its damper fully; (3) Adjust subsequent outlets to match that percentage; (4) Work from lowest to highest. This uses the lowest-performing outlet as reference. If it can't achieve design, the system needs modification (fan speed increase, reduced restriction).

questions.question: What is the Ak factor used for in airflow measurement?

choices.b: Converting hood or register face velocity to actual CFM accounting for free area

explanation.short: Ak factor (effective area) relates measured velocity to true airflow by accounting for actual free area of a diffuser or register.
explanation.detailed: Registers and diffusers don't have uniform velocity across their face - edges and louvers block airflow. The Ak factor (published by manufacturers) is the effective area that, when multiplied by average measured velocity, gives true CFM. CFM = Average Velocity × Ak. Without Ak, velocity-based measurements would be inaccurate. Capture hoods often have Ak built into their calibration.
explanation.how_to_find: Reference Ak factor usage in air measurement

questions.question: What is a terminal reheat system?

choices.a: A furnace with two heat exchangers
choices.b: A system that cools air centrally, then reheats at zone terminals for temperature control

explanation.short: Terminal reheat systems provide centrally cooled air to all zones, with zone reheat coils adding heat as needed for individual temperature control.
explanation.detailed: Terminal reheat provides excellent zone control but wastes energy by cooling then reheating. Central system cools air to lowest zone requirement; terminal coils (hot water or electric) at each zone add heat as needed. Energy codes restrict terminal reheat due to inefficiency. Modern alternatives: VAV (varies volume instead of reheating), or VAV with minimum airflow reheat where ventilation requires it.

questions.question: Why do VAV boxes have a minimum airflow setting?

choices.b: To maintain minimum ventilation air when zone load is satisfied

explanation.short: VAV minimums ensure adequate outdoor air ventilation even when the zone thermostat is satisfied.
explanation.detailed: VAV boxes modulate airflow based on thermostat demand - potentially to very low flow when satisfied. But ventilation air (per ASHRAE 62.1) must be maintained for occupant health. Minimum airflow settings ensure adequate ventilation regardless of thermal load. Minimums may be 30-50% of design or calculated per ventilation requirements. Some systems use demand-controlled ventilation to optimize.

questions.question: What characterizes a dual-duct HVAC system?

choices.b: Parallel hot and cold ducts with mixing boxes at each zone

explanation.short: Dual-duct systems run separate hot and cold supply ducts to mixing boxes that blend air for each zone's temperature requirement.
explanation.detailed: Dual-duct systems: central plant provides hot deck and cold deck; separate hot and cold ducts run throughout building; mixing boxes at each zone blend hot and cold air per thermostat. Excellent zone control but energy-inefficient (like terminal reheat) and space-intensive (two duct systems). Mostly found in older buildings. Modern systems use VAV or other more efficient approaches.

questions.question: What is an underfloor air distribution (UFAD) system?

choices.b: Supply air delivered through a raised floor plenum to floor-level diffusers

explanation.short: UFAD systems supply conditioned air through a pressurized plenum under a raised floor, with floor diffusers in the occupied zone.
explanation.detailed: Underfloor Air Distribution: raised access floor creates plenum; conditioned air is supplied into this plenum; floor diffusers or personal environmental control units deliver air to occupants at floor level; warm air rises and exhausts at ceiling. Benefits: better IAQ in breathing zone, personal control, flexible office layouts. Requires: raised floor (12+ inches), special diffusers, careful plenum sealing.

questions.question: How does displacement ventilation differ from traditional overhead supply?

choices.b: Supplies cool air at low velocity near floor level, which rises as it warms, exhausting at ceiling

explanation.short: Displacement ventilation supplies air at low velocity from near floor level; warm air naturally rises and is exhausted at the ceiling.
explanation.detailed: Displacement ventilation: supply air is slightly cooler than room temperature (typically 63-68°F) and delivered at very low velocity (< 50 FPM) from low wall or floor outlets. Cool air spreads along the floor, absorbs heat and contaminants as it rises past occupants, and exhausts at the ceiling. Creates stratified environment with better IAQ in occupied zone. Used in spaces with high ceilings or high heat loads.
